page.title: 13KETTLEWELL TRUST LORDS
page.content: After the Dissolution of the Monasteries, what was the Manor of Kettlewell came into the possession of a group of London merchants, who sold off areas of land to local lords or sheep farmers, who were gaining importance. By 1628 King Charles I gave control to these yeomen who eventually became Trust Lords, with their own steward, barmaster, gamekeeper, and shepherd. They had rights of turbary, drainage and repair, with mineral rights on their land, being self-reliant and showing active interest in the village. Today there are mainly local farming members, with a secretary, still called a barmaster. About seven Trust Lords meet annually, for charitable purposes, owning a small amount of land, dealing with old monuments or mineshafts on their land.
